title: Annual Income and Age: Which Statement Is False?
question_text:
Researchers surveyed working adults and asked them their yearly income and age.
Based on this table, which of the following statements is false?
tables:
x < 25,00025,001 < x <50,00050,001 < x < 100,000100,000 < x
Age under 303731141
Age 31-5011365123
Age over 508344543

choices.text: About $36\%$ of people surveyed are between $31$ and $50$ years old.
According to this chart, an experimenter has about a $10.8\%$ chance of randomly finding a $31-50$ year old who earns between $\$25{,}001$ to $\$50{,}000$ per year.
A segmented bar graph would be an appropriate way to display this data.
It appears from this data that older people earn more money.
Based on the data, reaching age $50$ guarantees a minimum income of $\$50{,}000$.

solution:
Choice 'A' is true; table total is $334$. Total of $31-50$ year olds is $121\text{ individuals}$. $\dfrac{121}{334} = 36.22\%$

Choice 'B' is true; $\dfrac{36}{334} = 10.8\%$.

Choice 'C' is true; segmented bar graphs are always useful for displaying data from an $r \times c$ contingency table.

Choice 'D' is true; age over $50$ has the highest proportion who make over $\$100,000$.

Choice 'E' is a false claim. There are data points on the table that indicate participants older than $50$ that have income in the two categories below $\$50{,}000$.
